page.title: 17Farming
page.content: A typical unit is family farm run by two or three generations.Most units are livestock rearing(sheep and beef), a number also milk cows for sale to the Milk Marketing Board but two farmers do bottle and sell their own untreated milk in the village.Sheep are mainly of the Swaledale breed, bred pure on the moor but crossed with a Blue-Faced Leicester tup(male sheep) in-bye to produce breeding females for final crossing by a meat breed tup such as a Suffolk or Texel.Cows are generally mated to a beef breed of bull such as a Charolais,Limousin or occasionally a traditional Hereford to produce calves for sale to fatteners.Most farmers see no change in their future pattern of farming but the impact of reduced subsidies could produce enormous social changes.
